Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The brain receives sensory input from the limbs via _______.
Options: A. Veins and the spinal cord, B. Nerves and the spinal cord, C. Bluetooth, D. Arteries and the spinal cord
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the model of the human body based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical Homunculus Model, B. Somatosensory Cortex Model, C. Phantom Limb Model, D. Neural Pathway Model Correct Option: A
Question 2: What type of therapy can help reduce phantom pain by creating a reflective illusion of the missing limb? Options: A. Virtual Reality Therapy, B. Mirror Box Therapy, C. Prosthetic Therapy, D. Cortical Stimulation Therapy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of the somatosensory cortex in relation to phantom limbs? Options: A. To process motor signals from the brain to the limbs, B. To process sensory signals from the body to the brain, C. To regulate the neural pathways after an amputation, D. To control the growth and shrinkage of cortical representation Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happens to the cortical representation of a body part when it receives increased sensory input? Options: A. It remains unchanged, B. It grows, C. It shrinks, D. It becomes inactive Correct Option: B
Question 5: A patient with phantom pain is considering treatment options. Which of the following therapies is most likely to be effective in reducing phantom pain? Options: A. Physical Therapy, B. Mirror Box Therapy, C. Occupational Therapy, D. Speech Therapy Correct Option: B
Question 6: A researcher is designing a new prosthetic limb to help alleviate phantom pain. What feature should the prosthetic have to achieve this goal? Options: A. Enhanced motor control, B. Increased sensory feedback, C. Improved durability, D. Reduced weight Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the brain's map of the body and phantom limb sensations? Options: A. The brain's map of the body is not related to phantom limb sensations, B. The brain's map of the body is responsible for phantom limb sensations, C. Phantom limb sensations are caused by a lack of sensory input to the brain's map of the body, D. The brain's map of the body is only responsible for motor control, not sensory perception Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the cause-and-effect connection between the loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn and the intensification of distress signals? Options: A. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn reduces the intensification of distress signals, B. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn has no effect on the intensification of distress signals, C. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn causes the intensification of distress signals, D. The intensification of distress signals causes the loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can the concept of cortical representation be combined with the idea of the brain's map of the body to understand phantom pain? Options: A. By recognizing that cortical representation is not related to phantom pain, B. By understanding that the brain's map of the body is not responsible for phantom pain, C. By realizing that changes in cortical representation can affect the brain's map of the body, leading to phantom pain, D. By acknowledging that the brain's map of the body is only responsible for motor control, not sensory perception Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a potential treatment approach that combines mirror box therapy and prosthetics to alleviate phantom pain? Options: A. Using mirror box therapy to enhance motor control in prosthetic limbs, B. Designing prosthetic limbs that provide sensory feedback to the brain, combined with mirror box therapy, C. Implementing mirror box therapy as a replacement for prosthetic limbs, D. Using prosthetic limbs to enhance the effectiveness of mirror box therapy in reducing phantom pain Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is a potential limitation of mirror box therapy in treating phantom pain? Options: A. It is too expensive, B. It is not widely available, C. It may not be effective for all patients, particularly those with complex or chronic phantom pain, D. It is too time-consuming Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is research into phantom limbs important for the field of prosthetics? Options: A. It can lead to the development of more advanced prosthetic limbs with enhanced motor control, B. It can provide insights into the neural mechanisms underlying phantom pain, leading to more effective treatments, C. It can improve the durability and comfort of prosthetic limbs, D. It can reduce the cost of prosthetic limbs Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: What is the primary function of the somatosensory cortex in relation to phantom limbs?**

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. A more similar question would be one that specifically asks about how the brain receives sensory input from the limbs.

A closer match can be found in the content of **Question 8**, but it still doesn't perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Since there isn't a perfect match, I will choose the question that is most relevant to the topic of how the brain receives sensory input.

**Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The "map" of body parts in the somatosensory cortex _______.
Options: A. Grows or shrinks, based on how much sensory input the brain receives from that body part, B. Grows but never shrinks, based on how much sensory input the brain receives from that body part, C. Shrinks but never grows, based on how much sensory input the brain receives from that body part, D. Is hardwired from birth and never changes
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the model of the human body based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical Homunculus Model, B. Somatosensory Cortex Model, C. Phantom Limb Model, D. Neural Pathway Model Correct Option: A
Question 2: What type of therapy can help reduce phantom pain by creating a reflective illusion of the missing limb? Options: A. Virtual Reality Therapy, B. Mirror Box Therapy, C. Prosthetic Therapy, D. Cortical Stimulation Therapy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of the somatosensory cortex in relation to phantom limbs? Options: A. To process motor signals from the brain to the limbs, B. To process sensory signals from the body to the brain, C. To regulate the neural pathways after an amputation, D. To control the growth and shrinkage of cortical representation Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happens to the cortical representation of a body part when it receives increased sensory input? Options: A. It remains unchanged, B. It grows, C. It shrinks, D. It becomes inactive Correct Option: B
Question 5: A patient with phantom pain is considering treatment options. Which of the following therapies is most likely to be effective in reducing phantom pain? Options: A. Physical Therapy, B. Mirror Box Therapy, C. Occupational Therapy, D. Speech Therapy Correct Option: B
Question 6: A researcher is designing a new prosthetic limb to help alleviate phantom pain. What feature should the prosthetic have to achieve this goal? Options: A. Enhanced motor control, B. Increased sensory feedback, C. Improved durability, D. Reduced weight Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the brain's map of the body and phantom limb sensations? Options: A. The brain's map of the body is not related to phantom limb sensations, B. The brain's map of the body is responsible for phantom limb sensations, C. Phantom limb sensations are caused by a lack of sensory input to the brain's map of the body, D. The brain's map of the body is only responsible for motor control, not sensory perception Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the cause-and-effect connection between the loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn and the intensification of distress signals? Options: A. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn reduces the intensification of distress signals, B. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn has no effect on the intensification of distress signals, C. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn causes the intensification of distress signals, D. The intensification of distress signals causes the loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can the concept of cortical representation be combined with the idea of the brain's map of the body to understand phantom pain? Options: A. By recognizing that cortical representation is not related to phantom pain, B. By understanding that the brain's map of the body is not responsible for phantom pain, C. By realizing that changes in cortical representation can affect the brain's map of the body, leading to phantom pain, D. By acknowledging that the brain's map of the body is only responsible for motor control, not sensory perception Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a potential treatment approach that combines mirror box therapy and prosthetics to alleviate phantom pain? Options: A. Using mirror box therapy to enhance motor control in prosthetic limbs, B. Designing prosthetic limbs that provide sensory feedback to the brain, combined with mirror box therapy, C. Implementing mirror box therapy as a replacement for prosthetic limbs, D. Using prosthetic limbs to enhance the effectiveness of mirror box therapy in reducing phantom pain Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is a potential limitation of mirror box therapy in treating phantom pain? Options: A. It is too expensive, B. It is not widely available, C. It may not be effective for all patients, particularly those with complex or chronic phantom pain, D. It is too time-consuming Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is research into phantom limbs important for the field of prosthetics? Options: A. It can lead to the development of more advanced prosthetic limbs with enhanced motor control, B. It can provide insights into the neural mechanisms underlying phantom pain, leading to more effective treatments, C. It can improve the durability and comfort of prosthetic limbs, D. It can reduce the cost of prosthetic limbs Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, an even more similar question is Question 9: How can the concept of cortical representation be combined with the idea of the brain's map of the body to understand phantom pain? Options: A. By realizing that changes in cortical representation can affect the brain's map of the body, leading to phantom pain, D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In an attempt to modify this "map," mirror box therapy is where a patient _______.
Options: A. Stands inside a large box full of mirrors, B. Puts their intact limb behind a mirror, C. Puts their amputated limb behind a mirror, D. Puts both their intact and amputated limbs into a box with a mirror on one side
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the model of the human body based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical Homunculus Model, B. Somatosensory Cortex Model, C. Phantom Limb Model, D. Neural Pathway Model Correct Option: A
Question 2: What type of therapy can help reduce phantom pain by creating a reflective illusion of the missing limb? Options: A. Virtual Reality Therapy, B. Mirror Box Therapy, C. Prosthetic Therapy, D. Cortical Stimulation Therapy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of the somatosensory cortex in relation to phantom limbs? Options: A. To process motor signals from the brain to the limbs, B. To process sensory signals from the body to the brain, C. To regulate the neural pathways after an amputation, D. To control the growth and shrinkage of cortical representation Correct Option: B

Question 7: What is the relationship between the brain's map of the body and phantom limb sensations? Options: A. The brain's map of the body is not related to phantom limb sensations, B. The brain's map of the body is responsible for phantom limb sensations, C. Phantom limb sensations are caused by a lack of sensory input to the brain's map of the body, D. Question 8: What is the cause-and-effect connection between the loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn and the intensification of distress signals? Options: A. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn reduces the intensification of distress signals, B. It can provide insights into the neural mechanisms underlying phantom pain, leading to more effective treatments, C. It can improve the durability and comfort of prosthetic limbs, D. Matching Response:

However, Question 2 does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it does not describe the action of putting the amputated limb behind a mirror. 

A more accurate match is Question 5, but it also does not describe the action.

However, upon closer inspection, Question 2's Option B and the Ground Truth MCQ's Correct Option C both imply the involvement of a mirror in the therapeutic process. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do some amputees not have any phantom sensations?
Options: A. The nerves have been completely cut off, B. We don’t know yet, C. Because their cortical maps are broken, D. They have them but can’t feel them
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the model of the human body based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical Homunculus Model, B. Somatosensory Cortex Model, C. Phantom Limb Model, D. Neural Pathway Model Correct Option: A
Question 2: What type of therapy can help reduce phantom pain by creating a reflective illusion of the missing limb? Options: A. Virtual Reality Therapy, B. Mirror Box Therapy, C. Prosthetic Therapy, D. Cortical Stimulation Therapy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of the somatosensory cortex in relation to phantom limbs? Options: A. To process motor signals from the brain to the limbs, B. To process sensory signals from the body to the brain, C. To regulate the neural pathways after an amputation, D. To control the growth and shrinkage of cortical representation Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happens to the cortical representation of a body part when it receives increased sensory input? Options: A. It remains unchanged, B. It grows, C. It shrinks, D. It becomes inactive Correct Option: B
Question 5: A patient with phantom pain is considering treatment options. Which of the following therapies is most likely to be effective in reducing phantom pain? Options: A. Physical Therapy, B. Mirror Box Therapy, C. Occupational Therapy, D. Speech Therapy Correct Option: B

The brain's map of the body is responsible for phantom limb sensations, C. Phantom limb sensations are caused by a lack of sensory input to the brain's map of the body, D. The brain's map of the body is only responsible for motor control, not sensory perception Correct Option: B

The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn reduces the intensification of distress signals, B. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn has no effect on the intensification of distress signals, C. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn causes the intensification of distress signals, D. The intensification of distress signals causes the loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn Correct Option: C

By realizing that changes in cortical representation can affect the brain's map of the body, leading to phantom pain, D. Implementing mirror box therapy as a replacement for prosthetic limbs, D. Using prosthetic limbs to enhance the effectiveness of mirror box therapy in reducing phantom pain Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is a potential limitation of mirror box therapy in treating phantom pain? Options: A. It is too expensive, B. It is not widely available, C. It may not be effective for all patients, particularly those with complex or chronic phantom pain, D. It is too time-consuming Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is research into phantom limbs important for the field of prosthetics? Options: A. It can lead to the development of more advanced prosthetic limbs with enhanced motor control, B. It can provide insights into the neural mechanisms underlying phantom pain, leading to more effective treatments, C. It can improve the durability and comfort of prosthetic limbs, D. It can reduce the cost of prosthetic limbs Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Phantom sensations raise the idea that bodily perceptions may be _______?
Options: A. Influenced by our environment, B. Influenced by memories, C. Influenced by movements, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A portly Miller, barely sober enough
to sit on his horse, rambles on about the flighty wife 
of a crotchety old carpenter and the scholar she takes as her lover. To get some time alone together, the scholar and the wife 
play various tricks that involve feigning madness, staging a biblical flood, and exposing themselves in public. But the parish clerk 
is also lusting after the wife, and comes by every night 
to sing outside her house. This becomes so tiresome 
that she tries to scare him away by hanging her rear end out the window 
for him to kiss. When this appears not to work, her scholar decides 
to try farting in the same position, but this time, the clerk 
is waiting with a red-hot poker. This might all sound like a bawdy joke, but it’s part of one of the most esteemed 
works of English literature ever created: The Canterbury Tales, which seamlessly blends the lofty 
and the lowly. The work consists of 24 stories, each told by one 
of Chaucer’s spirited characters. Narrators include 
familiar Medieval figures such as a Knight, a Clerk, and a Nun, and the less recognizable Reeve, and Mancible, and others. The Tales are written in Middle English, which often looks entirely different 
from the language spoken today. It was used between the 12th 
and 15th centuries, and evolved from Old English due to increased contact 
with European romantic languages after the Norman Conquest of 1066. Most of the Middle English alphabet 
is still familiar today, with the inclusion 
of a few archaic symbols, such as yogh, which denotes the y, j, or gh sound. The loquacious cast of the Tales 
first meet at the Tabard Inn in Southwark. They have a journey in common: a pilgrimage to Canterbury 
to visit the shrine of St. Thomas Beckett, a martyred archbishop who was murdered 
in his own Cathedral. Eager and nosy
for some personal details, the host of the Inn 
proposes a competition: whoever tells the best tale 
will be treated to dinner. If not for their pilgrimage, many of these figures would never 
have had the chance to interact. This is because Medieval society followed 
a feudal system that divided the clergy and nobility 
from the working classes, made up of peasants and serfs. By Chaucer’s time, a professional class of merchants 
and intellectuals had also emerged. Chaucer spent most of his life 
as a government official during the Hundred Years' War, traveling throughout Italy and France,
as well as his native England. This may have influenced
the panoramic vision of his work, and in the Tales,
no level of society is above mockery. Chaucer uses the quirks 
of the characters’ language – the ribald humor of the Cook, the solemn prose of the Parson, and the lofty notions of the Squire – to satirize their worldviews. The varied dialects, genres, 
and literary tropes also make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences 
entertained themselves. For instance, the Knight’s tale 
of courtly love, chivalry, and destiny riffs on romance, while the tales of working-class narrators
are generally comedies filled with scatological language, sexual deviance, and slapstick. This variation 
includes something for everyone, and that’s one reason why readers
continue to delight in the work in both Middle English and translation. While the narrative runs 
to over 17,000 lines, it's apparently unfinished, as the prologue ambitiously 
introduces 29 pilgrims and promises four stories apiece, and the innkeeper never crowns a victor. It’s possible that Chaucer was
so caught up in his sumptuous creations that he delayed picking a winner - or perhaps he was so fond 
of each character that he just couldn’t choose. Whatever the reason, this means that every reader
is free to judge; the question of who wins is up to you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Canterbury Tales is written in _______.
Options: A. Ancient English, B. Old English, C. Middle English, D. Modern English
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what century did the Norman Conquest of 1066 occur, leading to the evolution of Middle English? Options: A. 10th century, B. 11th century, C. 12th century, D. 15th century Correct Option: B
Question 2: Where do the characters in The Canterbury Tales first meet? Options: A. The shrine of St. Thomas Beckett, B. The Tabard Inn in Southwark, C. The Canterbury Cathedral, D. A local tavern Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is a key aspect of The Canterbury Tales that makes it a diverse and engaging read? Options: A. The use of a single narrative voice, B. The focus on a single social class, C. The varied dialects, genres, and literary tropes, D. The use of a linear narrative structure Correct Option: C
Question 4: What does the pilgrimage in The Canterbury Tales provide an opportunity for? Options: A. Characters from the same social class to interact, B. Characters from different social classes to interact, C. The narrator to tell a single, cohesive story, D. The author to express a single worldview Correct Option: B
Question 5: How could the themes of social satire and class commentary in The Canterbury Tales be applied to contemporary issues? Options: A. By using the work as a model for addressing issues of social inequality, B. By creating a new work that only focuses on the experiences of the upper class, C. By ignoring the relevance of social class in modern society, D. By using satire to reinforce existing social hierarchies Correct Option: A
Question 6: What literary device from The Canterbury Tales could be applied to modern-day storytelling and literary experimentation? Options: A. The use of a single narrative voice, B. The focus on a single genre, C. The use of diverse dialects and genres, D. The use of a linear narrative structure Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the cause-and-effect connection between the Norman Conquest of 1066 and the evolution of Middle English? Options: A. The Norman Conquest led to a decrease in the use of Middle English, B. The Norman Conquest had no impact on the evolution of Middle English, C. The Norman Conquest led to an increase in the use of Old English, D. The Norman Conquest led to the evolution of Middle English due to increased contact with European romantic languages Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does Chaucer use the quirks of the characters' language in The Canterbury Tales? Options: A. To create a sense of unity among the characters, B. To satirize their worldviews, C. To ignore the differences between social classes, D. To create a sense of ambiguity and uncertainty Correct Option: B
Question 9: What new narrative framework could be created by combining the idea of a pilgrimage with the concept of a competition for the best tale? Options: A. A narrative that only focuses on the experiences of the upper class, B. A narrative that blends different styles and voices, using the pilgrimage as a backdrop for a competition, C. A narrative that ignores the idea of social satire and class commentary, D. A narrative that uses a single genre and dialect to explore themes of identity Correct Option: B
Question 10: How could the diverse dialects and genres in The Canterbury Tales be used as inspiration for a new work of literature? Options: A. By creating a work that only uses a single dialect and genre, B. By blending different styles and voices to create a unique narrative, C. By ignoring the relevance of social class and language, D. By using a single narrative voice to explore themes of identity Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the significance of the work's unfinished state in The Canterbury Tales? Options: A. It provides a clear and definitive conclusion to the narrative, B. It leaves the reader with a sense of ambiguity and uncertainty, C. It has no impact on the reader's interpretation, D. It reinforces the themes of social satire and class commentary Correct Option: B
Question 12: How effective is Chaucer's satire in commenting on Medieval society in The Canterbury Tales? Options: A. It is completely ineffective and irrelevant, B. It is moderately effective, but limited in its scope, C. It is highly effective in commenting on the social issues of the time, D. It is only effective in commenting on the experiences of the upper class Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

Although Question 7 does not directly ask about the language in which The Canterbury Tales is written, it does discuss the evolution of Middle English, which is the correct answer to the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in Question 7 (D) also mentions Middle English, which aligns with the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C). 

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content. But among the available options, Question 7 is the closest match.

**Question 4: What does the pilgrimage in The Canterbury Tales provide an opportunity for?**

Although this question does not directly ask about the narrators of the 24 tales, it implies that the pilgrimage allows characters from different social classes to interact, which is related to the fact that the tales are narrated by different characters.

However, a closer match is not found among the generated MCQs. The original ground truth MCQ asks about the narrators of the 24 tales, but none of the generated MCQs directly address this question.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would choose **Question 4**. However, please note that this is not a perfect match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **4**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A portly Miller, barely sober enough
to sit on his horse, rambles on about the flighty wife 
of a crotchety old carpenter and the scholar she takes as her lover. To get some time alone together, the scholar and the wife 
play various tricks that involve feigning madness, staging a biblical flood, and exposing themselves in public. But the parish clerk 
is also lusting after the wife, and comes by every night 
to sing outside her house. This becomes so tiresome 
that she tries to scare him away by hanging her rear end out the window 
for him to kiss. When this appears not to work, her scholar decides 
to try farting in the same position, but this time, the clerk 
is waiting with a red-hot poker. This might all sound like a bawdy joke, but it’s part of one of the most esteemed 
works of English literature ever created: The Canterbury Tales, which seamlessly blends the lofty 
and the lowly. The work consists of 24 stories, each told by one 
of Chaucer’s spirited characters. Narrators include 
familiar Medieval figures such as a Knight, a Clerk, and a Nun, and the less recognizable Reeve, and Mancible, and others. The Tales are written in Middle English, which often looks entirely different 
from the language spoken today. It was used between the 12th 
and 15th centuries, and evolved from Old English due to increased contact 
with European romantic languages after the Norman Conquest of 1066. Most of the Middle English alphabet 
is still familiar today, with the inclusion 
of a few archaic symbols, such as yogh, which denotes the y, j, or gh sound. The loquacious cast of the Tales 
first meet at the Tabard Inn in Southwark. They have a journey in common: a pilgrimage to Canterbury 
to visit the shrine of St. Thomas Beckett, a martyred archbishop who was murdered 
in his own Cathedral. Eager and nosy
for some personal details, the host of the Inn 
proposes a competition: whoever tells the best tale 
will be treated to dinner. If not for their pilgrimage, many of these figures would never 
have had the chance to interact. This is because Medieval society followed 
a feudal system that divided the clergy and nobility 
from the working classes, made up of peasants and serfs. By Chaucer’s time, a professional class of merchants 
and intellectuals had also emerged. Chaucer spent most of his life 
as a government official during the Hundred Years' War, traveling throughout Italy and France,
as well as his native England. This may have influenced
the panoramic vision of his work, and in the Tales,
no level of society is above mockery. Chaucer uses the quirks 
of the characters’ language – the ribald humor of the Cook, the solemn prose of the Parson, and the lofty notions of the Squire – to satirize their worldviews. The varied dialects, genres, 
and literary tropes also make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences 
entertained themselves. For instance, the Knight’s tale 
of courtly love, chivalry, and destiny riffs on romance, while the tales of working-class narrators
are generally comedies filled with scatological language, sexual deviance, and slapstick. This variation 
includes something for everyone, and that’s one reason why readers
continue to delight in the work in both Middle English and translation. While the narrative runs 
to over 17,000 lines, it's apparently unfinished, as the prologue ambitiously 
introduces 29 pilgrims and promises four stories apiece, and the innkeeper never crowns a victor. It’s possible that Chaucer was
so caught up in his sumptuous creations that he delayed picking a winner - or perhaps he was so fond 
of each character that he just couldn’t choose. Whatever the reason, this means that every reader
is free to judge; the question of who wins is up to you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The characters are together because of _______.
Options: A. A funeral, B. A battle, C. A pilgrimage, D. A banquet
Correct Option: C

It is moderately effective, but limited in its scope, C. It is highly effective in commenting on the social issues of the time, D. It is only effective in commenting on the experiences of the upper class Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
A portly Miller, barely sober enough
to sit on his horse, rambles on about the flighty wife 
of a crotchety old carpenter and the scholar she takes as her lover. To get some time alone together, the scholar and the wife 
play various tricks that involve feigning madness, staging a biblical flood, and exposing themselves in public. But the parish clerk 
is also lusting after the wife, and comes by every night 
to sing outside her house. This becomes so tiresome 
that she tries to scare him away by hanging her rear end out the window 
for him to kiss. When this appears not to work, her scholar decides 
to try farting in the same position, but this time, the clerk 
is waiting with a red-hot poker. This might all sound like a bawdy joke, but it’s part of one of the most esteemed 
works of English literature ever created: The Canterbury Tales, which seamlessly blends the lofty 
and the lowly. The work consists of 24 stories, each told by one 
of Chaucer’s spirited characters. Narrators include 
familiar Medieval figures such as a Knight, a Clerk, and a Nun, and the less recognizable Reeve, and Mancible, and others. The Tales are written in Middle English, which often looks entirely different 
from the language spoken today. It was used between the 12th 
and 15th centuries, and evolved from Old English due to increased contact 
with European romantic languages after the Norman Conquest of 1066. Most of the Middle English alphabet 
is still familiar today, with the inclusion 
of a few archaic symbols, such as yogh, which denotes the y, j, or gh sound. The loquacious cast of the Tales 
first meet at the Tabard Inn in Southwark. They have a journey in common: a pilgrimage to Canterbury 
to visit the shrine of St. Thomas Beckett, a martyred archbishop who was murdered 
in his own Cathedral. Eager and nosy
for some personal details, the host of the Inn 
proposes a competition: whoever tells the best tale 
will be treated to dinner. If not for their pilgrimage, many of these figures would never 
have had the chance to interact. This is because Medieval society followed 
a feudal system that divided the clergy and nobility 
from the working classes, made up of peasants and serfs. By Chaucer’s time, a professional class of merchants 
and intellectuals had also emerged. Chaucer spent most of his life 
as a government official during the Hundred Years' War, traveling throughout Italy and France,
as well as his native England. This may have influenced
the panoramic vision of his work, and in the Tales,
no level of society is above mockery. Chaucer uses the quirks 
of the characters’ language – the ribald humor of the Cook, the solemn prose of the Parson, and the lofty notions of the Squire – to satirize their worldviews. The varied dialects, genres, 
and literary tropes also make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences 
entertained themselves. For instance, the Knight’s tale 
of courtly love, chivalry, and destiny riffs on romance, while the tales of working-class narrators
are generally comedies filled with scatological language, sexual deviance, and slapstick. This variation 
includes something for everyone, and that’s one reason why readers
continue to delight in the work in both Middle English and translation. While the narrative runs 
to over 17,000 lines, it's apparently unfinished, as the prologue ambitiously 
introduces 29 pilgrims and promises four stories apiece, and the innkeeper never crowns a victor. It’s possible that Chaucer was
so caught up in his sumptuous creations that he delayed picking a winner - or perhaps he was so fond 
of each character that he just couldn’t choose. Whatever the reason, this means that every reader
is free to judge; the question of who wins is up to you.

**Transcript**:
A portly Miller, barely sober enough
to sit on his horse, rambles on about the flighty wife 
of a crotchety old carpenter and the scholar she takes as her lover. To get some time alone together, the scholar and the wife 
play various tricks that involve feigning madness, staging a biblical flood, and exposing themselves in public. But the parish clerk 
is also lusting after the wife, and comes by every night 
to sing outside her house. This becomes so tiresome 
that she tries to scare him away by hanging her rear end out the window 
for him to kiss. When this appears not to work, her scholar decides 
to try farting in the same position, but this time, the clerk 
is waiting with a red-hot poker. This might all sound like a bawdy joke, but it’s part of one of the most esteemed 
works of English literature ever created: The Canterbury Tales, which seamlessly blends the lofty 
and the lowly. The work consists of 24 stories, each told by one 
of Chaucer’s spirited characters. Narrators include 
familiar Medieval figures such as a Knight, a Clerk, and a Nun, and the less recognizable Reeve, and Mancible, and others. The Tales are written in Middle English, which often looks entirely different 
from the language spoken today. It was used between the 12th 
and 15th centuries, and evolved from Old English due to increased contact 
with European romantic languages after the Norman Conquest of 1066. Most of the Middle English alphabet 
is still familiar today, with the inclusion 
of a few archaic symbols, such as yogh, which denotes the y, j, or gh sound. The loquacious cast of the Tales 
first meet at the Tabard Inn in Southwark. They have a journey in common: a pilgrimage to Canterbury

for some personal details, the host of the Inn

will be treated to dinner. If not for their pilgrimage, many of these figures would never 
have had the chance to interact. This is because Medieval society followed 
a feudal system that divided the clergy and nobility 
from the working classes, made up of peasants and serfs. By Chaucer’s time, a professional class of merchants 
and intellectuals had also emerged. Chaucer spent most of his life 
as a government official during the Hundred Years' War, traveling throughout Italy and France,
as well as his native England. This may have influenced
the panoramic vision of his work, and in the Tales,
no level of society is above mockery. Chaucer uses the quirks 
of the characters’ language – the ribald humor of the Cook, the solemn prose of the Parson, and the lofty notions of the Squire – to satirize their worldviews. The varied dialects, genres,

entertained themselves. For instance, the Knight’s tale

to over 17,000 lines, it's apparently unfinished, as the prologue ambitiously 
introduces 29 pilgrims and promises four stories apiece, and the innkeeper never crowns a victor. It’s possible that Chaucer was
so caught up in his sumptuous creations that he delayed picking a winner - or perhaps he was so fond 
of each character that he just couldn’t choose. Whatever the reason, this means that every reader
is free to judge; the question of who wins is up to you.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When trains began to shuttle people 
across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts 
insisted they wouldn’t catch on. Of course, we can’t predict exactly 
what the future will look like or what new inventions will populate it. But time and time again, we’ve also failed to predict 
that the technologies of the present will change the future. And recent research has revealed 
a similar pattern in our individual lives: we’re unable to predict change 
in ourselves. Three psychologists documented
our inability to predict personal change in a 2013 paper 
called, “The End of History Illusion.” Named after political scientist 
Francis Fukuyama’s prediction that liberal democracy 
was the final form of government, or as he called it, “the end of history,” their work highlights the way 
we see ourselves as finished products at any given moment. The researchers recruited over 
7,000 participants ages 18 to 68. They asked half of these participants to
report their current personality traits, values, and preferences, along with what each of those metrics 
had been ten years before. The other half described those features 
in their present selves, and predicted what 
they would be ten years in the future. Based on these answers, the researchers then calculated 
the degree of change each participant reported or predicted. For every age group in the sample, they compared the predicted changes 
to the reported changes. So they compared the degree to which 
18-year-olds thought they would change to the degree to which 28-year-olds 
reported they had changed. Overwhelmingly, at all ages, people’s future estimates of change 
came up short compared to the changes 
their older counterparts recalled. 20-year-olds expected 
to still like the same foods at 30, but 30-year-olds no longer 
had the same tastes. 30-year-olds predicted they’d still 
have the same best friend at 40, but 40-year-olds 
had lost touch with theirs. And 40-year-olds predicted 
they’d maintain the same core values that 50-year-olds had reconsidered. While older people changed less 
than younger people on the whole, they underestimated 
their capacity for change just as much. Wherever we are in life,
the end of history illusion persists: we tend to think that the bulk 
of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When was the research paper discussed in this lesson published?
Options: A. 1983, B. 1993, C. 2003, D. 2013
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who introduced the concept of the "End of History Illusion" in a 2013 paper? Options: A. Francis Fukuyama, B. Three psychologists, C. A philosopher and two economists, D. A historian and a sociologist, A. Francis Fukuyama, B. Three psychologists, C. A philosopher and two economists, D. A historian and a sociologist Correct Option: B
Question 2: How many participants were recruited for the study on the "End of History Illusion"? Options: A. Over 1,000, B. Over 5,000, C. Over 7,000, D. Over 10,000 Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main idea behind the "End of History Illusion"? Options: A. People tend to overestimate the changes they will undergo in the future., B. People tend to think that the bulk of their personal change is behind them., C. People tend to underestimate the importance of their current preferences., D. People tend to overinvest in past choices. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When trains began to shuttle people 
across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts 
insisted they wouldn’t catch on. Of course, we can’t predict exactly 
what the future will look like or what new inventions will populate it. But time and time again, we’ve also failed to predict 
that the technologies of the present will change the future. And recent research has revealed 
a similar pattern in our individual lives: we’re unable to predict change 
in ourselves. Three psychologists documented
our inability to predict personal change in a 2013 paper 
called, “The End of History Illusion.” Named after political scientist 
Francis Fukuyama’s prediction that liberal democracy 
was the final form of government, or as he called it, “the end of history,” their work highlights the way 
we see ourselves as finished products at any given moment. The researchers recruited over 
7,000 participants ages 18 to 68. They asked half of these participants to
report their current personality traits, values, and preferences, along with what each of those metrics 
had been ten years before. The other half described those features 
in their present selves, and predicted what 
they would be ten years in the future. Based on these answers, the researchers then calculated 
the degree of change each participant reported or predicted. For every age group in the sample, they compared the predicted changes 
to the reported changes. So they compared the degree to which 
18-year-olds thought they would change to the degree to which 28-year-olds 
reported they had changed. Overwhelmingly, at all ages, people’s future estimates of change 
came up short compared to the changes 
their older counterparts recalled. 20-year-olds expected 
to still like the same foods at 30, but 30-year-olds no longer 
had the same tastes. 30-year-olds predicted they’d still 
have the same best friend at 40, but 40-year-olds 
had lost touch with theirs. And 40-year-olds predicted 
they’d maintain the same core values that 50-year-olds had reconsidered. While older people changed less 
than younger people on the whole, they underestimated 
their capacity for change just as much. Wherever we are in life,
the end of history illusion persists: we tend to think that the bulk 
of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many participants did this research involve?
Options: A. 7, B. 70, C. 700, D. 7000
Correct Option: D

across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts

**Question 7: What relationship did the study highlight between age and the degree of change reported or predicted?**
Options: A. Older people changed more than younger people, B. Older people changed less than younger people, but still underestimated their capacity for change, C. Younger people changed more than older people, but still overestimated their capacity for change, D. There was no relationship between age and the degree of change
Correct Option: B

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it addresses the relationship between age and the degree of change, which is the main idea behind the ground truth MCQ. The options are also similar, with the correct option (B) stating that older people changed less than younger people, but still underestimated their capacity for change, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's correct option (C) stating that elderly people are the least susceptible to changes.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **7**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When trains began to shuttle people 
across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts 
insisted they wouldn’t catch on. Of course, we can’t predict exactly 
what the future will look like or what new inventions will populate it. But time and time again, we’ve also failed to predict 
that the technologies of the present will change the future. And recent research has revealed 
a similar pattern in our individual lives: we’re unable to predict change 
in ourselves. Three psychologists documented
our inability to predict personal change in a 2013 paper 
called, “The End of History Illusion.” Named after political scientist 
Francis Fukuyama’s prediction that liberal democracy 
was the final form of government, or as he called it, “the end of history,” their work highlights the way 
we see ourselves as finished products at any given moment. The researchers recruited over 
7,000 participants ages 18 to 68. They asked half of these participants to
report their current personality traits, values, and preferences, along with what each of those metrics 
had been ten years before. The other half described those features 
in their present selves, and predicted what 
they would be ten years in the future. Based on these answers, the researchers then calculated 
the degree of change each participant reported or predicted. For every age group in the sample, they compared the predicted changes 
to the reported changes. So they compared the degree to which 
18-year-olds thought they would change to the degree to which 28-year-olds 
reported they had changed. Overwhelmingly, at all ages, people’s future estimates of change 
came up short compared to the changes 
their older counterparts recalled. 20-year-olds expected 
to still like the same foods at 30, but 30-year-olds no longer 
had the same tastes. 30-year-olds predicted they’d still 
have the same best friend at 40, but 40-year-olds 
had lost touch with theirs. And 40-year-olds predicted 
they’d maintain the same core values that 50-year-olds had reconsidered. While older people changed less 
than younger people on the whole, they underestimated 
their capacity for change just as much. Wherever we are in life,
the end of history illusion persists: we tend to think that the bulk 
of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the End of History Illusion about?
Options: A. The relation between actual and perceived past changes, B. The relation between actual and expected future changes, C. The relation between past and future changes, D. Liberal democracy
Correct Option: B
