**Transcript**:
When trains began to shuttle people 
across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts 
insisted they wouldn’t catch on. Of course, we can’t predict exactly 
what the future will look like or what new inventions will populate it. But time and time again, we’ve also failed to predict 
that the technologies of the present will change the future. And recent research has revealed 
a similar pattern in our individual lives: we’re unable to predict change 
in ourselves. Three psychologists documented
our inability to predict personal change in a 2013 paper 
called, “The End of History Illusion.” Named after political scientist 
Francis Fukuyama’s prediction that liberal democracy 
was the final form of government, or as he called it, “the end of history,” their work highlights the way 
we see ourselves as finished products at any given moment. The researchers recruited over 
7,000 participants ages 18 to 68. They asked half of these participants to
report their current personality traits, values, and preferences, along with what each of those metrics 
had been ten years before. The other half described those features 
in their present selves, and predicted what 
they would be ten years in the future. Based on these answers, the researchers then calculated 
the degree of change each participant reported or predicted. For every age group in the sample, they compared the predicted changes 
to the reported changes. So they compared the degree to which 
18-year-olds thought they would change to the degree to which 28-year-olds 
reported they had changed. Overwhelmingly, at all ages, people’s future estimates of change 
came up short compared to the changes 
their older counterparts recalled. 20-year-olds expected 
to still like the same foods at 30, but 30-year-olds no longer 
had the same tastes. 30-year-olds predicted they’d still 
have the same best friend at 40, but 40-year-olds 
had lost touch with theirs. And 40-year-olds predicted 
they’d maintain the same core values that 50-year-olds had reconsidered. While older people changed less 
than younger people on the whole, they underestimated 
their capacity for change just as much. Wherever we are in life,
the end of history illusion persists: we tend to think that the bulk 
of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which phrase best sums up Poe’s guiding principle for writing fiction?
Options: A. Shock and awe, B. Unity of effect, C. The iceberg principle, D. Deep hidden meaning
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to Edgar Allan Poe, what two essential characteristics should a short story possess to achieve its purpose? Options: A. A complex plot and ambiguous language, B. A concise narrative that can be read in one sitting, and language where every word contributes to its purpose, C. A lengthy narrative with multiple themes and subplots, D. A narrative that explores multiple genres and styles Correct Option: B
Question 2: What literary effect does Poe aim to achieve in his stories by adhering to his rules for the short story form? Options: A. A sense of ambiguity and uncertainty, B. The unity of effect, an intense and singular experience, C. A clear moral message or lesson, D. A sense of fear and horror only Correct Option: B
Question 3: What underlying theme do Poe's stories often explore, despite their supernatural elements? Options: A. The consequences of violence and horror, B. The human mind and its propensity for self-destruction, C. The complexities of love and relationships, D. The supernatural and paranormal Correct Option: B
Question 4: What literary device does Poe pioneer in his stories to engage readers as active participants? Options: A. Symbolism and metaphor, B. Stream-of-consciousness narration, C. Unreliable narrators, D. Foreshadowing and suspense Correct Option: C
Question 5: What genre of story did Poe invent with "The Murders in the Rue Morgue"? Options: A. Horror, B. Science fiction, C. Detective story, D. Satire Correct Option: C
Question 6: What common theme is present in Poe's poetry, particularly in his best-known poems? Options: A. Love and relationships, B. Grief and mournful remembrance, C. Nature and the environment, D. Hope and optimism Correct Option: B
Question 7: What challenges did Poe face in his personal life, despite his literary success? Options: A. Wealth and fame, B. Poverty, personal struggles, and loss, C. Happiness and fulfillment, D. Stability and security Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does Poe's use of unreliable narrators affect the reader's experience? Options: A. It provides a clear and objective understanding of the story, B. It creates a sense of ambiguity and uncertainty, engaging readers as active participants, C. It leads to a straightforward and predictable plot, D. It results in a lack of emotional connection with the characters Correct Option: B
Question 9: What types of writing did Poe engage in, apart from horror stories? Options: A. Only poetry and short stories, B. Detective stories, satires, hoaxes, literary theory, and other experimental forms, C. Only novels and essays, D. Only plays and biographies Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions focus on Poe's guiding principle for writing fiction, with the correct answer being "unity of effect" or an intense and singular experience achieved through this unity. 

Although Question 1 and Question 2 both relate to Poe's writing principles, Question 2 more directly addresses the concept of "unity of effect" as a literary effect, making it a closer match to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In which of these literary genres did Poe not publish?
Options: A. Epic poem, B. Adventure novel, C. Satire, D. Detective fiction
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to Edgar Allan Poe, what two essential characteristics should a short story possess to achieve its purpose? Options: A. A complex plot and ambiguous language, B. A concise narrative that can be read in one sitting, and language where every word contributes to its purpose, C. A lengthy narrative with multiple themes and subplots, D. A narrative that explores multiple genres and styles Correct Option: B
Question 2: What literary effect does Poe aim to achieve in his stories by adhering to his rules for the short story form? Options: A. A sense of ambiguity and uncertainty, B. The unity of effect, an intense and singular experience, C. A clear moral message or lesson, D. A sense of fear and horror only Correct Option: B
Question 3: What underlying theme do Poe's stories often explore, despite their supernatural elements? Options: A. The consequences of violence and horror, B. The human mind and its propensity for self-destruction, C. The complexities of love and relationships, D. The supernatural and paranormal Correct Option: B
Question 4: What literary device does Poe pioneer in his stories to engage readers as active participants? Options: A. Symbolism and metaphor, B. Stream-of-consciousness narration, C. Unreliable narrators, D. Foreshadowing and suspense Correct Option: C
Question 5: What genre of story did Poe invent with "The Murders in the Rue Morgue"? Options: A. Horror, B. Science fiction, C. Detective story, D. Satire Correct Option: C
Question 6: What common theme is present in Poe's poetry, particularly in his best-known poems? Options: A. Love and relationships, B. Grief and mournful remembrance, C. Nature and the environment, D. Hope and optimism Correct Option: B
Question 7: What challenges did Poe face in his personal life, despite his literary success? Options: A. Wealth and fame, B. Poverty, personal struggles, and loss, C. Happiness and fulfillment, D. Stability and security Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does Poe's use of unreliable narrators affect the reader's experience? Options: A. It provides a clear and objective understanding of the story, B. It creates a sense of ambiguity and uncertainty, engaging readers as active participants, C. It leads to a straightforward and predictable plot, D. It results in a lack of emotional connection with the characters Correct Option: B
Question 9: What types of writing did Poe engage in, apart from horror stories? Options: A. Only poetry and short stories, B. Detective stories, satires, hoaxes, literary theory, and other experimental forms, C. Only novels and essays, D. Only plays and biographies Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

Although Question 9 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest in terms of question intent and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about a literary genre in which Poe did not publish, while Question 9 asks about the types of writing Poe engaged in apart from horror stories. However, Question 9's options provide information about the various genres and forms in which Poe did publish, indirectly addressing the ground truth MCQ's intent.

The correct answer to the ground truth MCQ is "Epic poem," which is not mentioned in Question 9's options. However, Question 9's options do mention several genres and forms in which Poe did publish, such as detective stories, satires, and poetry, which helps to eliminate those options as possible answers to the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9

and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ in terms of its focus on Poe's personal life.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 7: What challenges did Poe face in his personal life, despite his literary success?**

This question is related to the ground truth MCQ because it mentions Poe's personal life, which includes the loss of his mother and wife. However, the question and options are not directly equivalent.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 7 is the most similar generated MCQ, with an index of **7**. However, please note that this is not a direct match, and the generated MCQs do not include a question that specifically asks about the age at which Poe's mother and wife died.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take for most suburban homes to collapse?
Options: A. 10 years, B. 25 years, C. 75 years, D. 150 years
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated timeframe for sidewalks to be torn apart by weeds and tree roots after human disappearance? Options: A. 5 years, B. 10 years, C. 20 years, D. 50 years Correct Option: C
Question 2: How long do rubber tires last, serving as a habitat for mosquitoes to multiply? Options: A. 100 years, B. 500 years, C. Almost 1,000 years, D. 2,000 years Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the primary reason for the gradual decay of cities and buildings over time after human disappearance? Options: A. Natural disasters, B. Lack of maintenance and upkeep, C. Climate change, D. Economic collapse Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is one of the effects of reduced light pollution on the environment? Options: A. Increased CO2 levels, B. Decreased bird migrations, C. Increased energy consumption, D. Saving over a billion birds each year Correct Option: D
Question 5: What would likely happen to underground rail systems like those in London, Moscow, and New York City if humans were to suddenly disappear? Options: A. They would continue to function normally, B. They would be immediately destroyed, C. They would flood within days due to abandoned drainage pumps, D. They would remain intact for centuries Correct Option: C
Question 6: What should be a key focus area for a community developing a strategy for sustainable urban planning and design? Options: A. Increasing energy consumption, B. Preserving natural habitats and ecosystems, C. Promoting invasive species, D. Reducing green spaces Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does human infrastructure influence the spread of non-native species in post-human ecosystems? Options: A. Human infrastructure prevents the spread of non-native species, B. Human infrastructure has no impact on the spread of non-native species, C. Human infrastructure facilitates the spread of non-native species, D. Human infrastructure only affects native species Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the decay of urban areas compare to the decay of rural areas after human disappearance? Options: A. Urban areas decay faster than rural areas, B. Rural areas decay faster than urban areas, C. Urban and rural areas decay at the same rate, D. There is no comparison between urban and rural areas Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is a potential outcome of integrating the concepts of human impact, environmental decay, and ecosystem recovery in urban planning and design? Options: A. Increased environmental degradation, B. Decreased economic growth, C. More sustainable and resilient cities, D. Reduced human population Correct Option: C
Question 10: How can understanding the relationship between infrastructure collapse and non-native species spread inform strategies for sustainable urban planning and design? Options: A. By prioritizing economic growth over environmental concerns, B. By ignoring the potential consequences of invasive species, C. By developing strategies to mitigate the impact of human activities on the environment, D. By promoting the spread of non-native species Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a valid critique of the predictions made about the post-human world? Options: A. The predictions are too optimistic about the resilience of human infrastructure, B. The predictions are too pessimistic about the recovery of the Earth's climate, C. The predictions are based on insufficient data and research, D. The predictions are too focused on the short-term effects of human disappearance Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is preserving natural habitats and ecosystems crucial? Options: A. It is not necessary to preserve natural habitats and ecosystems, B. Preserving natural habitats and ecosystems is too expensive, C. Preserving natural habitats and ecosystems is crucial for maintaining biodiversity and ecosystem services, D. Preserving natural habitats and ecosystems is only important for human recreation Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. However, the content of Question 1 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. 

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that specifically asks about the timeframe for suburban homes to collapse. Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would choose Question 8, as it discusses the decay of urban and rural areas, which is somewhat related to the collapse of suburban homes.

But since Question 8 does not specifically ask about the timeframe for suburban homes to collapse, I will choose Question 1 as a more suitable match, as it at least discusses a related topic (timeframe for sidewalks to be torn apart) and has a similar format (asking about a specific timeframe).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these animals thrives after humans leave the earth?
Options: A. Dogs, B. Cockroaches, C. Horses, D. Mosquitos
Correct Option: D

By developing strategies to mitigate the impact of human activities on the environment, D. By promoting the spread of non-native species Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these things lasts the longest on a post-human earth?
Options: A. Mt Rushmore, B. Suspension bridges, C. Bronze statues, D. Rubber Tires
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the estimated timeframe for sidewalks to be torn apart by weeds and tree roots after human disappearance? Options: A. 5 years, B. 10 years, C. 20 years, D. 50 years Correct Option: C

Question 3: What is the primary reason for the gradual decay of cities and buildings over time after human disappearance? Options: A. Natural disasters, B. Lack of maintenance and upkeep, C. Climate change, D. Economic collapse Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is one of the effects of reduced light pollution on the environment? Options: A. Increased CO2 levels, B. Decreased bird migrations, C. Increased energy consumption, D. Saving over a billion birds each year Correct Option: D
Question 5: What would likely happen to underground rail systems like those in London, Moscow, and New York City if humans were to suddenly disappear? Options: A. They would continue to function normally, B. They would be immediately destroyed, C. They would flood within days due to abandoned drainage pumps, D. They would remain intact for centuries Correct Option: C
Question 6: What should be a key focus area for a community developing a strategy for sustainable urban planning and design? Options: A. Increasing energy consumption, B. Preserving natural habitats and ecosystems, C. Promoting invasive species, D. Reducing green spaces Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does human infrastructure influence the spread of non-native species in post-human ecosystems? Options: A. Human infrastructure prevents the spread of non-native species, B. Human infrastructure has no impact on the spread of non-native species, C. Human infrastructure facilitates the spread of non-native species, D. Human infrastructure only affects native species Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the decay of urban areas compare to the decay of rural areas after human disappearance? Options: A. Urban areas decay faster than rural areas, B. Rural areas decay faster than urban areas, C. Urban and rural areas decay at the same rate, D. There is no comparison between urban and rural areas Correct Option: A

Increased environmental degradation, B. Decreased economic growth, C. More sustainable and resilient cities, D. Reduced human population Correct Option: C

By prioritizing economic growth over environmental concerns, B. By ignoring the potential consequences of invasive species, C. By developing strategies to mitigate the impact of human activities on the environment, D. By promoting the spread of non-native species Correct Option: C

The predictions are too pessimistic about the recovery of the Earth's climate, C. The predictions are based on insufficient data and research, D. The predictions are too focused on the short-term effects of human disappearance Correct Option: C

Preserving natural habitats and ecosystems is only important for human recreation Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT a side effect of decaying cities?
Options: A. Plant life withers underneath fallen buildings, B. Crushed concrete in nearby tributaries, C. Lower soil acidity on new forest floors, D. Fossilized techno cities
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens 
as their ingredients make their way through our bodies, and how we benefit physically 
when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000 
chemical substances into contact with the body’s tissues. From the start, tar, 
a black, resinous material, begins to coat the teeth and gums, damaging tooth enamel, 
and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages 
nerve-endings in the nose, causing loss of smell. Inside the airways and lungs, smoke increases 
the likelihood of infections, as well as chronic diseases
like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is 
to keep the airways clean. It then fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs that enable the exchange 
of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and blood. A toxic gas called carbon monoxide 
crosses that membrane into the blood, binding to hemoglobin and displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported
around the body. That’s one of the reasons smoking 
can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath. Within about 10 seconds, the bloodstream carries a stimulant 
called nicotine to the brain, triggering the release of dopamine 
and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals 
from the cigarette simultaneously cause constriction 
of blood vessels and damage their delicate 
endothelial lining, restricting blood flow. These vascular effects lead 
to thickening of blood vessel walls and enhance blood platelet stickiness, increasing the likelihood 
that clots will form and trigger heart attacks and strokes. Many of the chemicals inside cigarettes 
can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate 
and long-lasting physical benefits. Just 20 minutes after 
a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Chemicals introduced into the body by smoking include all of the following EXCEPT:
Options: A. Nicotine, B. Methemoglobin, C. Arsenic, D. Carbon monoxide
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of chemical substances found in cigarettes? Options: A. 1,000, B. 3,000, C. 5,000, D. 7,000 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the name of the black, resinous material in cigarettes that damages tooth enamel and causes decay? Options: A. Tar, B. Nicotine, C. Carbon monoxide, D. Dopamine Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the primary cause of chronic diseases like bronchitis and emphysema in smokers? Options: A. Nicotine addiction, B. Damage to the airways and lungs, C. Increased heart rate and blood pressure, D. Decreased risk of heart disease Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a common effect of nicotine withdrawal in people who quit smoking? Options: A. Temporary anxiety and depression, B. Increased heart rate and blood pressure, C. Decreased risk of heart disease, D. Improved eyesight Correct Option: A
Question 5: A person who smokes a pack of cigarettes a day wants to quit. What is a recommended strategy to help them quit? Options: A. Gradually increase the number of cigarettes smoked per day, B. Use nicotine replacement therapy and counseling, C. Try to quit cold turkey without any assistance, D. Reduce physical activity to minimize withdrawal symptoms Correct Option: B
Question 6: A doctor is advising a patient on the benefits of quitting smoking. What is a key point the doctor should emphasize? Options: A. The patient will experience temporary anxiety and depression, B. The patient's risk of heart disease and stroke will decrease significantly, C. The patient will need to use nicotine replacement therapy for the rest of their life, D. The patient's eyesight will not improve after quitting Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the established relationship between smoking and cancer in the United States? Options: A. Smoking causes about one in ten cancer deaths, B. Smoking causes about one in three cancer deaths, C. Smoking has no significant relationship with cancer deaths, D. Smoking reduces the risk of cancer deaths Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary cause-and-effect connection between smoking and heart disease? Options: A. Smoking leads to a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, B. Smoking leads to vascular effects and increased risk of heart attacks and strokes, C. Smoking has no significant effect on heart disease, D. Smoking reduces the risk of heart disease Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is a recommended combination of strategies to increase the chances of quitting smoking? Options: A. Nicotine replacement therapy, counseling, and support groups, B. Gradually increasing the number of cigarettes smoked per day and trying to quit cold turkey, C. Reducing physical activity and using nicotine replacement therapy, D. Trying to quit cold turkey and reducing physical activity Correct Option: A
Question 10: How can the understanding of the mechanisms of harm caused by smoking inform public health efforts? Options: A. By creating effective public health campaigns to encourage people to quit, B. By reducing funding for smoking cessation programs, C. By increasing the number of cigarettes sold per day, D. By minimizing the risks associated with smoking Correct Option: A
Question 11: What is a key factor in evaluating the effectiveness of nicotine replacement therapy in helping smokers quit? Options: A. The cost of the therapy, B. The evidence-based research supporting its effectiveness, C. The number of cigarettes smoked per day, D. The temporary anxiety and depression experienced during withdrawal Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a justification for public health campaigns to encourage people to quit smoking? Options: A. The significant health benefits of quitting, including reduced risk of heart disease and stroke, B. The increased revenue generated by cigarette sales, C. The temporary anxiety and depression experienced during withdrawal, D. The lack of evidence supporting the effectiveness of quitting Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 8: What is the primary cause-and-effect connection between smoking and heart disease? Options: A. Smoking leads to a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, B. Smoking leads to vascular effects and increased risk of heart attacks and strokes, C. Smoking has no significant effect on heart disease, D. Smoking reduces the risk of heart disease Correct Option: B**

However, this question does not match the ground truth MCQ exactly. A more suitable match is not present among the provided generated MCQs, but if I had to choose one, I would choose Question 8 for its mention of specific chemicals and effects (though not exactly matching the ground truth MCQ).

But since it doesn't match the ground truth MCQ exactly, I will try to find a better match.

A better match would be a question that asks about the chemicals introduced into the body by smoking. Unfortunately, no such question exists among the provided generated MCQs.

However, if I had to choose one that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ, I would choose:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:

The temporary anxiety and depression experienced during withdrawal, D. The lack of evidence supporting the effectiveness of quitting Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Smoking reduces the risk of heart disease Correct Option: B**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens 
as their ingredients make their way through our bodies, and how we benefit physically 
when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000 
chemical substances into contact with the body’s tissues. From the start, tar, 
a black, resinous material, begins to coat the teeth and gums, damaging tooth enamel, 
and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages 
nerve-endings in the nose, causing loss of smell. Inside the airways and lungs, smoke increases 
the likelihood of infections, as well as chronic diseases
like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is 
to keep the airways clean. It then fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs that enable the exchange 
of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and blood. A toxic gas called carbon monoxide 
crosses that membrane into the blood, binding to hemoglobin and displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported
around the body. That’s one of the reasons smoking 
can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath. Within about 10 seconds, the bloodstream carries a stimulant 
called nicotine to the brain, triggering the release of dopamine 
and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals 
from the cigarette simultaneously cause constriction 
of blood vessels and damage their delicate 
endothelial lining, restricting blood flow. These vascular effects lead 
to thickening of blood vessel walls and enhance blood platelet stickiness, increasing the likelihood 
that clots will form and trigger heart attacks and strokes. Many of the chemicals inside cigarettes 
can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate 
and long-lasting physical benefits. Just 20 minutes after 
a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT an effect of smoking:
Options: A. Constriction of blood vessels, B. Damage to the endothelial lining, C. Thickening of blood vessel walls, D. Reduced stickiness of blood platelets
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of chemical substances found in cigarettes? Options: A. 1,000, B. 3,000, C. 5,000, D. 7,000 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the name of the black, resinous material in cigarettes that damages tooth enamel and causes decay? Options: A. Tar, B. Nicotine, C. Carbon monoxide, D. Dopamine Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the primary cause of chronic diseases like bronchitis and emphysema in smokers? Options: A. Nicotine addiction, B. Damage to the airways and lungs, C. Increased heart rate and blood pressure, D. Decreased risk of heart disease Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a common effect of nicotine withdrawal in people who quit smoking? Options: A. Temporary anxiety and depression, B. Increased heart rate and blood pressure, C. Decreased risk of heart disease, D. Improved eyesight Correct Option: A
Question 5: A person who smokes a pack of cigarettes a day wants to quit. What is a recommended strategy to help them quit? Options: A. Gradually increase the number of cigarettes smoked per day, B. Use nicotine replacement therapy and counseling, C. Try to quit cold turkey without any assistance, D. Reduce physical activity to minimize withdrawal symptoms Correct Option: B
Question 6: A doctor is advising a patient on the benefits of quitting smoking. What is a key point the doctor should emphasize? Options: A. The patient will experience temporary anxiety and depression, B. The patient's risk of heart disease and stroke will decrease significantly, C. The patient will need to use nicotine replacement therapy for the rest of their life, D. The patient's eyesight will not improve after quitting Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the established relationship between smoking and cancer in the United States? Options: A. Smoking causes about one in ten cancer deaths, B. Smoking causes about one in three cancer deaths, C. Smoking has no significant relationship with cancer deaths, D. Smoking reduces the risk of cancer deaths Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary cause-and-effect connection between smoking and heart disease? Options: A. Smoking leads to a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, B. Smoking leads to vascular effects and increased risk of heart attacks and strokes, C. Smoking has no significant effect on heart disease, D. Smoking reduces the risk of heart disease Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is a recommended combination of strategies to increase the chances of quitting smoking? Options: A. Nicotine replacement therapy, counseling, and support groups, B. Gradually increasing the number of cigarettes smoked per day and trying to quit cold turkey, C. Reducing physical activity and using nicotine replacement therapy, D. Trying to quit cold turkey and reducing physical activity Correct Option: A
Question 10: How can the understanding of the mechanisms of harm caused by smoking inform public health efforts? Options: A. By creating effective public health campaigns to encourage people to quit, B. By reducing funding for smoking cessation programs, C. By increasing the number of cigarettes sold per day, D. By minimizing the risks associated with smoking Correct Option: A
Question 11: What is a key factor in evaluating the effectiveness of nicotine replacement therapy in helping smokers quit? Options: A. The cost of the therapy, B. The evidence-based research supporting its effectiveness, C. The number of cigarettes smoked per day, D. The temporary anxiety and depression experienced during withdrawal Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a justification for public health campaigns to encourage people to quit smoking? Options: A. The significant health benefits of quitting, including reduced risk of heart disease and stroke, B. The increased revenue generated by cigarette sales, C. The temporary anxiety and depression experienced during withdrawal, D. The lack of evidence supporting the effectiveness of quitting Correct Option: A

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens 
as their ingredients make their way through our bodies, and how we benefit physically 
when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000 
chemical substances into contact with the body’s tissues. From the start, tar, 
a black, resinous material, begins to coat the teeth and gums, damaging tooth enamel, 
and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages 
nerve-endings in the nose, causing loss of smell. Inside the airways and lungs, smoke increases 
the likelihood of infections, as well as chronic diseases
like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is 
to keep the airways clean. It then fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs that enable the exchange 
of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and blood. A toxic gas called carbon monoxide 
crosses that membrane into the blood, binding to hemoglobin and displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported
around the body. That’s one of the reasons smoking 
can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath. Within about 10 seconds, the bloodstream carries a stimulant 
called nicotine to the brain, triggering the release of dopamine 
and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals 
from the cigarette simultaneously cause constriction 
of blood vessels and damage their delicate 
endothelial lining, restricting blood flow. These vascular effects lead 
to thickening of blood vessel walls and enhance blood platelet stickiness, increasing the likelihood 
that clots will form and trigger heart attacks and strokes. Many of the chemicals inside cigarettes 
can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate 
and long-lasting physical benefits. Just 20 minutes after 
a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: All of the following help smokers stay cigarette-free EXCEPT:
Options: A. Oral antibiotic therapy, B. Nicotine replacement patches, C. Cognitive behavioral therapy, D. Moderate intensity exercise
Correct Option: A
