Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is also called _______.
Options: A. Multiple sclerosis, B. Motor neuron disease, C. Lou Gehrig’s disease, D. Motor neuron disease and Lou Gehrig's disease
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what age was Stephen Hawking diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)? Options: A. 18, B. 21, C. 30, D. 40 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is another name for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)? Options: A. Parkinson's Disease, B. Alzheimer's Disease, C. Lou Gehrig's Disease, D. Huntington's Disease Correct Option: C
Question 3: What type of muscle control is primarily affected in ALS patients? Options: A. Involuntary muscle control, B. Voluntary muscle control, C. Cardiac muscle control, D. Smooth muscle control Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happens to motor neurons in ALS patients? Options: A. They regenerate and multiply, B. They remain unaffected, C. They degenerate and disrupt the signaling system, D. They become stronger and more resilient Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is a potential benefit of understanding the causes and effects of ALS? Options: A. Developing new treatments and therapies, B. Identifying a single genetic mutation responsible for ALS, C. Reducing funding for ALS research, D. Limiting healthcare professionals' ability to diagnose ALS Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the primary role of upper motor neurons in the neuromuscular system? Options: A. To transmit messages from the spinal cord to the brain, B. To transmit messages from the brain to the lower motor neurons, C. To control involuntary muscle movements, D. To regulate the immune system Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the degeneration of motor neurons and the disruption of the signaling system in ALS patients? Options: A. The degeneration of motor neurons has no effect on the signaling system, B. The degeneration of motor neurons strengthens the signaling system, C. The degeneration of motor neurons disrupts the signaling system between the brain and muscles, D. The degeneration of motor neurons only affects the lower motor neurons Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a key difference between hereditary and sporadic cases of ALS? Options: A. Hereditary cases are caused by environmental factors, while sporadic cases are caused by genetic mutations, B. Hereditary cases are caused by genetic mutations, while sporadic cases may be caused by environmental factors or toxins, C. Hereditary cases are more common than sporadic cases, D. Sporadic cases are only caused by lifestyle factors Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can the understanding of ALS's impact on the neuromuscular system be combined with the development of new treatments and therapies? Options: A. By focusing solely on the neuromuscular system, B. By integrating knowledge of the neuromuscular system with the development of new treatments and therapies to slow disease progression, C. By ignoring the neuromuscular system's role in ALS, D. By developing treatments that only target the lower motor neurons Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a potential connection between ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases? Options: A. They are all caused by the same genetic mutation, B. They all affect the same area of the brain, C. They may share common underlying mechanisms, such as protein misfolding, D. They are all curable with the same treatment Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a crucial aspect of evaluating the effectiveness of current treatments and therapies for ALS? Options: A. Ignoring patient outcomes and focusing solely on the cost of treatment, B. Considering only the benefits of treatment and ignoring potential risks, C. Assessing both the benefits and risks of treatment and considering patient outcomes, D. Evaluating treatment effectiveness based solely on animal studies Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is it essential to justify the need for increased funding and support for ALS research and treatment? Options: A. Because ALS is a rare disease that affects few people, B. Because current treatments are sufficient, and no further research is needed, C. Because ALS is a devastating disease with no cure, and increased funding can accelerate research and improve patient outcomes, D. Because ALS research is too expensive and not cost-effective Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the typical life expectancy of ALS patients after diagnosis? Options: A. 1-2 years, B. 2-5 years, C. 5-10 years, D. 10-20 years Correct Option: B
Question 14: What percentage of ALS cases are hereditary? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40% Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is a potential cause of motor neuron degeneration in ALS patients? Options: A. Misfolded proteins and clumps, B. Genetic mutations only, C. Environmental factors only, D. Lifestyle factors only Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

However, it's worth noting that Question 2 does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it only provides one alternative name for ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease), whereas the ground truth MCQ lists two alternative names (Motor neuron disease and Lou Gehrig's disease). 

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would choose Question 2, but I would recommend creating a new generated MCQ that more accurately reflects the ground truth MCQ. 

Here's an example of a new generated MCQ that more closely matches the ground truth MCQ:

Question: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is also called _______.
Options: A. Multiple sclerosis, B. Motor neuron disease, C. Lou Gehrig’s disease, D. Motor neuron disease and Lou Gehrig's disease

This new generated MCQ more accurately reflects the content and options of the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary

after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,

because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with

that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses

called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues,

mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how many people are diagnosed with ALS worldwide per year?
Options: A. About 30,000, B. About 100,000, C. About 120,000, D. About 1,000,000
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what age was Stephen Hawking diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)? Options: A. 18, B. 21, C. 30, D. 40 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is another name for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)? Options: A. Parkinson's Disease, B. Alzheimer's Disease, C. Lou Gehrig's Disease, D. Huntington's Disease Correct Option: C
Question 3: What type of muscle control is primarily affected in ALS patients? Options: A. Involuntary muscle control, B. Voluntary muscle control, C. Cardiac muscle control, D. Smooth muscle control Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happens to motor neurons in ALS patients? Options: A. They regenerate and multiply, B. They remain unaffected, C. They degenerate and disrupt the signaling system, D. They become stronger and more resilient Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is a potential benefit of understanding the causes and effects of ALS? Options: A. Developing new treatments and therapies, B. Identifying a single genetic mutation responsible for ALS, C. Reducing funding for ALS research, D. Limiting healthcare professionals' ability to diagnose ALS Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the primary role of upper motor neurons in the neuromuscular system? Options: A. To transmit messages from the spinal cord to the brain, B. To transmit messages from the brain to the lower motor neurons, C. To control involuntary muscle movements, D. To regulate the immune system Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the degeneration of motor neurons and the disruption of the signaling system in ALS patients? Options: A. The degeneration of motor neurons has no effect on the signaling system, B. The degeneration of motor neurons strengthens the signaling system, C. The degeneration of motor neurons disrupts the signaling system between the brain and muscles, D. The degeneration of motor neurons only affects the lower motor neurons Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a key difference between hereditary and sporadic cases of ALS? Options: A. Hereditary cases are caused by environmental factors, while sporadic cases are caused by genetic mutations, B. Hereditary cases are caused by genetic mutations, while sporadic cases may be caused by environmental factors or toxins, C. Hereditary cases are more common than sporadic cases, D. Sporadic cases are only caused by lifestyle factors Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can the understanding of ALS's impact on the neuromuscular system be combined with the development of new treatments and therapies? Options: A. By focusing solely on the neuromuscular system, B. By integrating knowledge of the neuromuscular system with the development of new treatments and therapies to slow disease progression, C. By ignoring the neuromuscular system's role in ALS, D. By developing treatments that only target the lower motor neurons Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a potential connection between ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases? Options: A. They are all caused by the same genetic mutation, B. They all affect the same area of the brain, C. They may share common underlying mechanisms, such as protein misfolding, D. They are all curable with the same treatment Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a crucial aspect of evaluating the effectiveness of current treatments and therapies for ALS? Options: A. Ignoring patient outcomes and focusing solely on the cost of treatment, B. Considering only the benefits of treatment and ignoring potential risks, C. Assessing both the benefits and risks of treatment and considering patient outcomes, D. Evaluating treatment effectiveness based solely on animal studies Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is it essential to justify the need for increased funding and support for ALS research and treatment? Options: A. Because ALS is a rare disease that affects few people, B. Because current treatments are sufficient, and no further research is needed, C. Because ALS is a devastating disease with no cure, and increased funding can accelerate research and improve patient outcomes, D. Because ALS research is too expensive and not cost-effective Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the typical life expectancy of ALS patients after diagnosis? Options: A. 1-2 years, B. 2-5 years, C. 5-10 years, D. 10-20 years Correct Option: B
Question 14: What percentage of ALS cases are hereditary? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40% Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is a potential cause of motor neuron degeneration in ALS patients? Options: A. Misfolded proteins and clumps, B. Genetic mutations only, C. Environmental factors only, D. Lifestyle factors only Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of ALS is not hereditary?
Options: A. About 10%, B. About 40%, C. About 50%, D. About 90%
Correct Option: D

Hereditary cases are caused by genetic mutations, while sporadic cases may be caused by environmental factors or toxins, C. Hereditary cases are more common than sporadic cases, D. Sporadic cases are only caused by lifestyle factors Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can the understanding of ALS's impact on the neuromuscular system be combined with the development of new treatments and therapies? Options: A. Because ALS research is too expensive and not cost-effective Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Most people with ALS _______.
Options: A. Lose the ability to voluntarily move their muscles, B. Are cognitively impaired, C. Lose the ability to see, D. Lose the ability to hear
Correct Option: A

The degeneration of motor neurons has no effect on the signaling system, B. The degeneration of motor neurons strengthens the signaling system, C. The degeneration of motor neurons disrupts the signaling system between the brain and muscles, D. The degeneration of motor neurons only affects the lower motor neurons Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a key difference between hereditary and sporadic cases of ALS? Options: A. Hereditary cases are caused by environmental factors, while sporadic cases are caused by genetic mutations, B. Hereditary cases are caused by genetic mutations, while sporadic cases may be caused by environmental factors or toxins, C. Hereditary cases are more common than sporadic cases, D. Sporadic cases are only caused by lifestyle factors Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can the understanding of ALS's impact on the neuromuscular system be combined with the development of new treatments and therapies? Options: A. By focusing solely on the neuromuscular system, B. By integrating knowledge of the neuromuscular system with the development of new treatments and therapies to slow disease progression, C. By ignoring the neuromuscular system's role in ALS, D. By developing treatments that only target the lower motor neurons Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a potential connection between ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases? Options: A. They are all caused by the same genetic mutation, B. They all affect the same area of the brain, C. They may share common underlying mechanisms, such as protein misfolding, D. They are all curable with the same treatment Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a crucial aspect of evaluating the effectiveness of current treatments and therapies for ALS? Options: A. Ignoring patient outcomes and focusing solely on the cost of treatment, B. Considering only the benefits of treatment and ignoring potential risks, C. Assessing both the benefits and risks of treatment and considering patient outcomes, D. Evaluating treatment effectiveness based solely on animal studies Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is it essential to justify the need for increased funding and support for ALS research and treatment? Options: A. Because ALS is a rare disease that affects few people, B. Because current treatments are sufficient, and no further research is needed, C. Because ALS is a devastating disease with no cure, and increased funding can accelerate research and improve patient outcomes, D. Because ALS research is too expensive and not cost-effective Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the typical life expectancy of ALS patients after diagnosis? Options: A. 1-2 years, B. 2-5 years, C. 5-10 years, D. 10-20 years Correct Option: B
Question 14: What percentage of ALS cases are hereditary? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40% Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is a potential cause of motor neuron degeneration in ALS patients? Options: A. Misfolded proteins and clumps, B. Genetic mutations only, C. Environmental factors only, D. Lifestyle factors only Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What type of muscle control is primarily affected in ALS patients? 

Options: A. Involuntary muscle control, B. Voluntary muscle control, C. Cardiac muscle control, D. Smooth muscle control 

Correct Option: B

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Reasoning: The ground truth MCQ asks about the effect of ALS on most people, and the correct option states that most people with ALS lose the ability to voluntarily move their muscles. The generated MCQ (Question 3) directly addresses the type of muscle control primarily affected in ALS patients, which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in the generated MCQ (B. Voluntary muscle control) matches the information provided in the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where is Pluto located?
Options: A. The Kuiper Belt, B. The Prometheus Belt, C. The Andromeda Belt, D. The Odysseus Belt
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: On July 4, 2015, approximately how far was the NASA spacecraft New Horizons from Earth? Options: A. 1 billion kilometers, B. 5 billion kilometers, C. 10 billion kilometers, D. 20 billion kilometers Correct Option: B
Question 2: How many state-of-the-art scientific instruments was New Horizons equipped with? Options: A. 5, B. 6, C. 7, D. 8 Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary objective of the New Horizons mission? Options: A. To explore Jupiter and its moons, B. To explore Pluto, collect scientific data, and then explore the Kuiper Belt, C. To explore the Kuiper Belt and its many small planets, D. To explore the Sun's corona Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did New Horizons have to be designed to be both reliable and lightweight? Options: A. To withstand extreme temperatures in space, B. To reach Pluto before its atmosphere froze and the surface became shrouded in darkness, C. To carry a large crew, D. To collect a large amount of data Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the effect of the gravity assist from Jupiter on New Horizons' speed? Options: A. It decreased New Horizons' speed, B. It increased New Horizons' speed to approximately 50,000 kilometers per hour, C. It had no effect on New Horizons' speed, D. It increased New Horizons' speed by a small amount Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the distance between Earth and Pluto affect the design and operation of the New Horizons mission? Options: A. It allowed for real-time communication between Earth and the spacecraft, B. It required the spacecraft to be designed for a long-duration mission with automated systems, C. It had no effect on the design and operation of the mission, D. It allowed for a crew to be on board the spacecraft Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is a significant discovery made by New Horizons about Pluto? Options: A. Pluto has a highly eccentric orbit, B. Pluto has a surface composed primarily of liquid water, C. Pluto has a 1000-kilometer-wide glacier called Sputnik Planitia, D. Pluto has a thin atmosphere Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do the discoveries made by New Horizons contribute to our understanding of the solar system? Options: A. By providing insights into the formation of black holes, B. By providing insights into the formation and evolution of our solar system, C. By providing insights into the formation of galaxies, D. By providing insights into the formation of stars Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the next destination for the New Horizons spacecraft after exploring Pluto? Options: A. Jupiter's moon Europa, B. The Kuiper Belt Object 2014 MU69, C. The Sun's corona, D. Mars Correct Option: B
Question 10: How would you assess the success of the New Horizons mission? Options: A. It was partially successful in achieving its objectives, B. It was completely unsuccessful in achieving its objectives, C. It was completely successful in achieving its objectives and making new discoveries, D. It was too early to assess the success of the mission Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a justification for the cost and resources invested in the New Horizons mission? Options: A. The mission provided insights into the formation of black holes, B. The mission provided valuable insights into the formation and evolution of our solar system, C. The mission was a waste of resources, D. The mission was too expensive Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is a potential application of the technology used in New Horizons? Options: A. Exploring the ocean floor, B. Exploring other distant objects in our solar system, C. Studying the Earth's atmosphere, D. Developing new medical technologies Correct Option: B
Question 13: What was the cause of the loss of contact between New Horizons and Earth? Options: A. A solar flare, B. A malfunction in the spacecraft's communication system, C. A reboot of the spacecraft's main computer, D. Unknown Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the significance of the Kuiper Belt in our solar system? Options: A. It is a region of intense radiation, B. It is a region of extreme temperatures, C. It is a region containing many small planets and ancient icy objects, D. It is a region devoid of any celestial objects Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is unique about Pluto's surface feature, Sputnik Planitia? Options: A. It is a large crater, B. It is a mountain range, C. It is a glacier composed primarily of frozen nitrogen, D. It is a valley Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

Question 14: What is the significance of the Kuiper Belt in our solar system? 
Options: A. It is a region of intense radiation, B. It is a region of extreme temperatures, C. It is a region containing many small planets and ancient icy objects, D. It is a region devoid of any celestial objects 
Correct Option: C

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it asks about the location or region where Pluto is found, and the correct answer mentions the Kuiper Belt. Although the question is not an exact match, it is the closest one in terms of content and intent.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 14

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What were the objectives of New Horizons?
Options: A. To explore Pluto, B. To collect as much scientific data as possible and transmit it back, C. To explore farther out in the Kuiper Belt, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is REX?
Options: A. The Radio Science Experiment designed to test for radiation, B. The Radio Science Experiment designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure and temperature, C. The Radio Science Experiment designed to test for signs of life on Pluto, D. The Radio Science Experiment designed to take photographs
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take Pluto to complete a full orbit?
Options: A. 50 Earth years, B. 127 Earth years, C. 248 Earth years, D. 683 Earth years
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The finish line's in sight
and you put on an extra burst of speed. As your legs pick up the pace,
your breathing gets deeper, your heart pounds faster, and sweat pours over your skin. How does this substance
suddenly materialize and what exactly is its purpose? There are a number of scenarios
that can make us sweat: eating spicy foods, nervousness, and when we're sick. But exercise is probably the most familiar
and common. In that case, sweating happens 
as a response to movement triggered deep inside your cells. As you increase your pace,
your muscles work harder, increasing their demand for energy. A process called cellular respiration consumes glucose 
and oxygen to form ATP, the energy currency of the cell. Much of this process takes place
in structures called mitochondria. The more you move, the harder mitochondria work
to supply your body with energy. All this work comes at a cost, though. As the cells break down the ATP,
they release heat. The heat stimulates temperature sensors
throughout your body. Those receptors detect the excess heat
being produced by your muscle cells and communicate that information
to the hypothalamus, which regulates body temperature. The hypothalamus responds by sending signals out through 
the sympathetic nervous system to the sweat glands in your skin. These are distributed all over the body with especially high concentrations
on the palms of your hands, the soles of your feet, and on your head. When a sweat gland first receives
the signal, the fluid surrounding the cells
in its coiled base contains high amounts 
of sodium and chloride. The cells pump these ions
into a hollow tube that runs through the sweat gland. Then, because it's saltier inside
the tube than outside, water moves into the tube by osmosis. As what's called the primary secretion
builds up in the bottom of the tube, water pressure pushes it up
into the long straight part of the duct. Before it seeps onto the skin, cells lining the tube will reclaim
as much salt as possible so the process can continue. The water in sweat absorbs 
your body's heat energy and then evaporates off of you
when it reaches the surface, which in turn lowers your temperature. This process, 
known as evaporative cooling, was an important adaptation 
for our ancestors. This cooling effect isn't only helpful
during exercise. We sweat in many other scenarios, too. Eating particularly spicy food makes some
people sweat profusely from their faces. That happens because spices trigger
the same neural response in the brain that activates temperature receptors,
which usually respond to increased heat. Sweating is also part of 
the fight or flight response stimulated by stressful scenarios,
like asking someone on a date or interviewing for a job. This happens because adrenaline
stimulates muscle activity and causes blood vessels to widen, two responses that increase heat
and trigger the sweating response. And sweating also occurs 
when we get sick. When we're feverish,
we sweat because infections stimulate the hypothalamus 
to increase muscle activity, which in turn releases 
more energy as heat. That increases your overall temperature, a protective mechanism that makes your
body less habitable for infectious agents. Like with running, sweating helps
your body vent that heat. When the fever's over 
or you've won your race, your temperature receptors 
sense the decrease in heat and the hypothalamus brings 
your sweating response to an end. In some cases, like after a run, the hypothalamus also signals
to your body that you need to replenish the water
that you've oozed out. So, when you're pushing yourself
to reach that next goal, you can think of sweat as your body's
very own calibrator, enabling you to go that extra mile.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following scenarios will you not sweat?
Options: A. Exercise, B. Eating spicy food, C. Overhydrating, D. Nervousness
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary energy currency of the cell? Options: A. Glucose, B. ATP (adenosine triphosphate), C. Oxygen, D. Sodium Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which organelle within cells is responsible for generating most of the cell's energy through cellular respiration? Options: A. Mitochondria, B. Hypothalamus, C. Nucleus, D. Endoplasmic reticulum Correct Option: A
Question 3: What triggers sweating as a response to increased energy demands and heat production in the body? Options: A. Eating spicy foods, B. Exercise, C. Infections, D. Stress Correct Option: B
Question 4: Which part of the brain responds to temperature changes by sending signals to the sweat glands to regulate body temperature? Options: A. Hypothalamus, B. Cerebellum, C. Cerebral cortex, D. Brainstem Correct Option: A
Question 5: In what type of environment can understanding how sweating regulates body temperature help athletes optimize their performance? Options: A. Cold and dry environments, B. Hot and humid environments, C. High-altitude environments, D. Low-altitude environments Correct Option: B
Question 6: Recognizing the role of sweating in thermoregulation can inform strategies for managing which type of illness? Options: A. Respiratory illnesses, B. Cardiovascular illnesses, C. Heat-related illnesses, D. Neurological illnesses Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between exercise, energy demands, and heat production that leads to sweating? Options: A. Increased energy demands lead to decreased heat production, B. Increased energy demands lead to increased heat production, C. Decreased energy demands lead to increased heat production, D. Decreased energy demands lead to decreased heat production Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does the hypothalamus respond to changes in body temperature? Options: A. Increased heat leads to cessation of sweating, while decreased heat leads to sweating, B. Increased heat leads to sweating, while decreased heat leads to cessation of sweating, C. Increased heat leads to increased heart rate, while decreased heat leads to decreased heart rate, D. Increased heat leads to decreased blood pressure, while decreased heat leads to increased blood pressure Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the result of integrating knowledge of cellular respiration, mitochondrial function, and thermoregulation? Options: A. Understanding the complex processes underlying digestion, B. Understanding the complex processes underlying sweating, C. Understanding the complex processes underlying respiration, D. Understanding the complex processes underlying circulation Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the result of combining understanding of the hypothalamus's role in thermoregulation with the concept of evaporative cooling? Options: A. Appreciation of the importance of shivering in temperature regulation, B. Appreciation of the importance of sweating in temperature regulation, C. Appreciation of the importance of vasodilation in temperature regulation, D. Appreciation of the importance of vasoconstriction in temperature regulation Correct Option: B
Question 11: What can be evaluated by considering the effectiveness of sweating as a thermoregulatory mechanism in different environments and scenarios? Options: A. The role of the hypothalamus in regulating body temperature, B. The importance of sweating in maintaining homeostasis, C. The impact of external factors on sweating and thermoregulation, D. The effectiveness of sweating as a thermoregulatory mechanism Correct Option: D
Question 12: What can be critiqued by examining the role of the hypothalamus in regulating body temperature and its response to various stimuli? Options: A. The role of the sympathetic nervous system in regulating body temperature, B. The role of the parasympathetic nervous system in regulating body temperature, C. The role of the hypothalamus in regulating body temperature, D. The role of the cerebral cortex in regulating body temperature Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 3 has some similarities with the ground truth MCQ. However, the options in Question 3 do not include a scenario where sweating does not occur.

A closer match would be a question that asks about scenarios where sweating does or does not occur. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 2
Matching Prompt:
